body:
It also happend for me with google drive after all retries

```
{"level":"debug","msg":"8 go routines active\n","source":"cmd/cmd.go:298","time":"2022-09-17T15:31:22.280164+00:00"}
2022/09/17 15:31:22 Failed to copy: googleapi: Error 403: User rate limit exceeded., userRateLimitExceeded
```

command
```
rclone --config ./logs/rclone/process_id_1.conf copy --drive-server-side-across-configs -vv --ignore-existing --tpslimit 3 --transfers 3 --low-level-retries 3 --drive-chunk-size 32M --drive-copy-shortcut-content --drive-acknowledge-abuse --use-json-log --log-file=./logs/rclone/process_id_1.log src001: dst001:test/offline/aaa/```

It looks like rclone isn't logging fatal errors with the rclone logger.

So any places where we have `log.Fatalf` or `log.Fatal` we need to be calling a new `fs.Fatalf` function.

I am experiencing this issue as well via librclone.

For instance if calling `rc/error` to test error handling, the output in the terminal looks like this:

`2023/07/17 03:37:32 ERROR : rc: "rc/error": error: arbitrary error on input map[]`
@xenago I think this is the same problem. Calling `log.Fatalf`. What we need to do is create an `fs.Fatalf` and then go through the entire codebase changing `log.Fatalf` to `fs.Fatalf`.

I wanted to use `rclone` in Qt application as a backed for uploading files to wherever.

Parsing text messages to distinguish progress/"Connecting to server"/errors "by hand" felt silly, so I've found out that there's `--use-json-long`, but as other's already noted, it's inconsistent. For example, I do get DEBUG messages as JSON:

```
{"level":"debug","msg":"low level retry 10/10 (error dial tcp 127.0.0.1:2121: connect: connection refused)","object":"pacer","objectType":"string","source":"fs/pacer.go:90","time":"2024-05-28T14:11:04.442773+03:00"}
```

But errors in plaintext:

```
Failed to create file system for \":ftp:\": NewFs: failed to make FTP connection to \"127.0.0.1:2121\": dial tcp 127.0.0.1:2121: connect: connection refused
```

Also, v1.66.0 no longer use "ERROR :" suffix for fatal errors as 1.53.3 in Debian 11 did :/ .

So yeah.. consistency is a bit lacking.

> I think this is the same problem. Calling `log.Fatalf`. What we need to do is create an `fs.Fatalf` and then go through the entire codebase changing `log.Fatalf` to `fs.Fatalf`.

This is still the problem if someone wants to have a go at fixing it.

We should probably have a lint rule to detect use of `log.Print` and `log.Fatal` also - @albertony can we do that?

> We should probably have a lint rule to detect use of `log.Print` and `log.Fatal` also - @albertony can we do that?

Haven't tried it, but it seems using [go-ruleguard](https://github.com/quasilyte/go-ruleguard) could be an elegant solution for defining our own custom linting rules. Golangci-lint integrates [go-critic](https://github.com/go-critic/go-critic), which in turn includes ruleguard [go-ruleguard](https://github.com/quasilyte/go-ruleguard).
I have tested my suggestion to use ruleguard checks here: https://github.com/rclone/rclone/pull/7884.

issue.title: Gocritic lint

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the purpose of this change?

Basic gocritic linting via golangci-lint was enabled in https://github.com/rclone/rclone/pull/8009.

This continues on that PR with additional features, primarily enabling custom linting rules with ruleguard via gocritic.

It then adds custom linting rules for log statements, with suggestions to use `fs.` instead of `log.`, which is required for `--use-json-log` to properly make log output in JSON format. This fixes https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/6038.

Note:
- After ruleguard files are changed, lint cache will not be automatically invalidated. GitHub Actions cache must be manually deleted, unless waiting for the transition to a new year-week number because then it changes the cache key and therefore will the next lint will run without cache. Running locally, command `golangci-lint cache clean` can be used to test changes to ruleguard files.
  > //Note that when used from golangci-lint (using the gocritic linter configured
  > // with the ruleguard check), because rule files are not handled by
  > // golangci-lint itself, changes will not invalidate the golangci-lint cache,
  > // and you must manually clean to cache (golangci-lint cache clean) for them to
  > // be considered, as explained here:
  > // https://www.quasilyte.dev/blog/post/ruleguard/#using-from-the-golangci-lint


#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

<!--
Link issues and relevant forum posts here.
-->

#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [ ] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [ ] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)
